Lars Clausen wrote:
> Other things I ran across in this little run:
> 
> The date stamp used for the file name uses GMT rather than localtime, I
> just created this arc file where the time in the name isn't the same as
> the time on the file itself:
> -rw-rw-r--    1 lc       lc        1425953 Jul  8 12:33 IAH-20040708103136-00001-pc770.sb.statsbiblioteket.dk.arc.gz
> Getting the time right with daylights savings is a little tricky, but I
> believe I have some code for it somewhere.

This is by design; we believe GMT is the best timestamp to use consistently.
Otherwise, every timestamp would require an extra timezone indicator in
order to be compared against others from other crawling efforts. Historically,
the timestamps in ARCs and ARC names are GMT (or at least were always
supposed to be).

So, the few remaining places where local time may appear (such as some of
the per-class debug logging to STDERR) will eventually be eliminated.

Of course, when displaying content to local audiences, it may make sense
to convert to local time.

> It was a small crawl, yet it made three arc files.  I thought they were
> suppose to go up to 100MB each, so why did I get
> 
> -rw-rw-r--    1 lc       lc          46310 Jul  8 12:32 IAH-20040708103136-00000-pc770.sb.statsbiblioteket.dk.arc.gz
> -rw-rw-r--    1 lc       lc        1425953 Jul  8 12:33 IAH-20040708103136-00001-pc770.sb.statsbiblioteket.dk.arc.gz
> -rw-rw-r--    1 lc       lc           2202 Jul  8 12:32 IAH-20040708103200-00002-pc770.sb.statsbiblioteket.dk.arc.gz
> 
> It's not that there's a system to what files are where.

If you know beforehand that a crawl will fit in a single ARC, or that you are
not concerned with the bottleneck that can occur when many worker threads
are all waiting for a single ARC to become ready for writing, you can set the
ARC pool size to '1' in the ARCWriterProcessor settings.

'3' is the default; the optimum for different kinds of crawls hasn't been
determined. Since there's no foolproof way for the software to estimate
in advance how many ARCs (and how much parallelism) may be needed, this has
to be set by the operator.

> The settings page is huge, it may be an idea (at some point) to figure
> out which settings are the most frequently used, so the rest (which
> should be most of them) can go in the expert settings.

Agreed, we'd like to better group the settings to avoid overwhelming
the operator with little-used or hard-to-understand options.
